sentence.text: Role of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors in the growth arrest at senescence in human prostate epithelial and uroepithelial cells.
Cellular senescence has been proposed to be an in vitro and in vivo block that cells must overcome in order to immortalize and become tumorigenic.
To characterize these pathways, we focused on changes in the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors and their binding partners that underlie the cell cycle arrest at senescence.
As a model, we utilized normal human prostate epithelial cell (HPEC) and human uroepithelial cell (HUC) cultures.
After 30-40 population doublings cells became growth-arrested in G0/1 with a threefold decrease in ____-associated activity, a point defined as pre-senescence.
Temporally following this growth arrest, the cells develop a senescence morphology and express ________________________________________ (___________).
Levels of ___(_____) and ___(____) rise in HUCs during progressive passages, whereas only ___ increases in HPEC cultures.
The induced expression of ___, similar to ___, produces a senescent-like phenotype.
___, ________, ___(_____) and ___(____) decrease in both cell types.
We find that ___, ___(____) and ___(_____) are transiently elevated in HPECs and HUCs at the pre-senescent growth arrest, then return to low proliferating levels at terminal senescence.
Analysis of ___, ___(____), ___(_____), ___(_____), and ___(____) reveals altered expression in immortalized, non-tumorigenic HPV16 E6 and E7 prostate lines and in tumorigenic prostate cancer cells.

These results indicate: (i) the existence of a subset of growth inhibiting genes elevated at the onset of the senescence, (ii) a distinct class of genes involved in the maintenance of senescence, and (iii) the frequent inactivation of these pathways during immortalization.
Positive inotropic responses mediated by endothelin _____ and _____ receptors in human myocardial trabeculae.
The aim of the present study was to determine possible inotropic effects mediated by endothelin _____ and _____ receptors in human myocardial trabeculae from the right atrium and the left ventricle.
Isolated trabeculae from human hearts were paced at 1.0 Hz in tissue baths, and changes in isometric contractile force upon exposure to agonist were studied.
____________ (____) and ____ had a strong positive inotropic effect in all trabeculae.
____ was significantly more potent than ____ in both atrial (P < 0.001) and ventricular (P < 0.05) trabeculae.

Preincubation with the ______________ antagonist FR139317 (1 microM) decreased significantly (P < 0.005) the potency of _____ in both atrial and ventricular trabeculae, without any significant changes in Emax (maximum effect obtained with an agonist).
The ______________ agonist IRL 1620 had a positive inotropic effect only in some trabeculae, and the ______________ antagonist BQ 788 (1 microM) almost completely blocked this effect.
These results suggest that both _____ and _____ receptors mediate positive inotropic responses at both the atrial and ventricular level in the human heart.
Apoptotic proteins. ___ and _____ related pathways.
_____ and ___ are two proteins that have critical roles in the regulation of apoptosis and the cell cycle.

The authors review how these two proteins are thought to control the opposing events of proliferation and apoptosis and examine whether their well-documented biological roles in tumorigenesis can be applied to the vascular system.
A comparative study of __________ and _____________ expression in de novo and ex adenoma carcinoma of the colorectum.
An apparent exception to the colorectal adenoma-carcinoma carcinogenetic pathway is the so-called "de novo" carcinoma which has no evidence of adenoma in its vicinity.

Despite the fact that they are often quite small, these lesions appear to be more aggressive (i.e., greater likelihood of lymph-node metastases) than carcinomas that clearly arise from surrounding adenomas exadenoma carcinoma.

The purpose of the present comparative immunohistochemical study was to compare rates of cell adhesion molecule (__________) and protease [_____________ (____)] expression in groups of de novo (n=64) and ex adenoma (n=42) lesions in order to see whether their more aggressive behavior is associated with decreased cell adhesion and increased protease expression.
The rates of extensive ____ expression and decreased __________ expression were significantly higher in the de novo group (P=0.014 and 0.005, respectively).
Histopathologically, the de novo group also had a significantly higher percentage of cases with an infiltrative invasion pattern.
These differences highlight the more aggressive phenotype of the de novo colorectal carcinoma and fit with their greater invasive potential.
Immunohistochemical analysis of epidermal growth factor receptor family members in stage I non-small cell lung cancer.
BACKGROUND: To elucidate the relationship between the expression of epidermal growth factor receptor family members (______, neu/______, ______, and ______) and tumor recurrence.
METHODS: We used immunohistochemistry to examine the expression of four epidermal growth factor receptor family members in 73 patients with stage I non-small cell lung cancer.

RESULTS: Using Cox univariate analysis, we determined that angiolymphatic tumor emboli and non-well-differentiated tumor cells were two significant conventional pathologic predictors of tumor recurrence, and that ______ and ______ were also significant predictors.
Co-expression of ______+, -3+, or expression of three or more epidermal growth factor receptor family members had a significant effect on lung cancer recurrence.
A stepwise multivariate Cox proportional hazards regression analysis provided a predictive model for tumor recurrence.
CONCLUSIONS: The present study shows that in patients with a non-well-differentiated tumor, overexpression of ______ is a useful marker for predicting tumor recurrence.
The present study also confirmed that ______ expression increased in proportion to the loss of tumor differentiation.
The correlation between ______ and distant metastasis was good.
Potential cellular signatures of viral infections in human hematopoietic cells.

Expression profiling of cellular genes was performed using a 10,000 cDNA human gene array in order to identify expression changes following chronic infection of human hematopoietic cells with Kaposi's Sarcoma-associated Virus (KSHV) also known as Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and Human T cell leukemia virus-1 (HTLV-1).

We performed cell-free in vitro infection of primary bone marrow derived ____+ cells using semi-purified HHV8 and a mature ____ dependent T cell line, KIT 225, using highly concentrated viral stocks prepared from an infectious molecular clone of HTLV-1.
Thirty days post infection, mRNA was isolated from infected cultures and uninfected controls and submitted for microarray analysis.
More than 400 genes were differentially expressed more than two-fold following HHV8 infection of primary bone marrow derived ____+ cells.
Of these 400, ______________________________ (____), _________, TBP-associated factor, eukaryotic elongation factor and _____ were up-regulated more than 3.5 fold.
In contrast, less than 100 genes were differentially expressed more than two-fold following chronic infection of a mature T cell line with HTLV-1.
Of these, only ____ was up-regulated more than 3.5 fold.
These data may provide insight into cellular signatures of infection useful for diagnosis of infection as well as potential targets for therapeutic intervention.
The genetics of host resistance and susceptibility to tuberculosis.
The study of human genomics has the potential to aid our understanding of the interindividual and interpopulation differences in susceptibility to tuberculosis.
Resistance to infection is affected by the ability of macrophages to phagocytose and destroy the bacilli.
Several genes are involved in this process, and two have been the focus of recent interest: the _____________________________________ (______) gene and the genes coding for the __________________.
Susceptibility genes have also been discovered--for example, one on the X chromosome that may explain the increased susceptibility of males to tuberculosis.
Studies have also focused on the variations in virulence of the bacillus in both its drug-susceptible and drug-resistant forms.

These mechanisms must be understood in order to prevent, or combat, the emergence of a virulent, multidrug-resistant form of the bacillus that would be uncontrollable by means of today's treatment strategies.
Regulated trafficking of neurotransmitter transporters: common notes but different melodies.
The activity of biogenic amine and amino acid neurotransmitters is limited by presynaptic and astrocytic Na(+)-dependent transport systems.
Their functional importance is underscored by the observation that these transporters are the targets of broad classes of psychotherapeutic agents, including antidepressants and stimulants.
Early studies suggested that the activity of these transporters can be fine tuned by a number of different signaling pathways.
In the past five years, several groups have provided compelling evidence that changing the cell surface availability of these transporters contributes to this fine tuning.

This regulated trafficking can result in rapid (within minutes) increases or decreases in the plasma membrane expression of these transporters and is independent of transcriptional or translational control mechanisms.

Many of the same signaling molecules, including ________________ (___), ______________________________________________ (_____), and protein phosphatase, regulate the transporters for different neurotransmitters.
In addition to these classical receptor activated pathways, transporter substrates also regulate activity and cell surface expression of these transporters.
In fact, some of the transporters form complexes with signaling molecules.

Given the functional and genetic similarities of these transporters, it is not surprising that the same signaling molecules regulate their trafficking, but except for the molecules, the actual effects on individual transporters are remarkably different.
It is as if the same musical notes have been rearranged into several different melodies.
Instability of extracellular matrix gene expression in primary cell culture of fibroblasts from human vocal fold lamina propria and tracheal
scar.Primary fibroblast cell cultures were established from lamina propria of human vocal fold and tracheal scar.
There exists a crucial need to provide new tools for studying voice biology, and one of the first steps is the development of a human primary laryngeal cell culture bank.

Because cell lines can lose their differentiated phenotype in culture across passages, documentation of gene expression must be determined for passage populations, for us to have knowledge of cell behavior in vitro.

Comparison of messenger RNA gene expression of extracellular matrix proteins (_____________, ___________, _______, __________________________, _____________, ___________, ____, ____________, and _______) across cell passages (3, 4, 5, 6, 10, and 12 fornormal laminapropria and 3, 4, 5, 6, and 10 for tracheal scar) revealed varied growth patterns.

Cytogenetic analysis demonstrated relative stability of the karyotypes across passages for the tracheal scar cell cultures, whereas the karyotypes of the normal lamina propria fibroblasts showed instability in in vitro cultures.
Recommendations for use of primary cell cultures for further studies of gene expression are made.
Identification of a new member of the tumor necrosis factor family and its receptor, a human ortholog of mouse GITR.
The tumor necrosis factor (TNF) and TNF receptor (TNFR) gene superfamilies regulate diverse biological functions, including cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival [1] [2] [3].

We have identified a new TNF-related ligand, designated human ___________ (______), and its human receptor (_____), an ortholog of the recently discovered murine ___________________________________________________ [4].
The ______ gene mapped to chromosome 1q23, near the gene for the TNF homolog ___/___________ [5].
The _____ gene mapped to chromosome 1p36, near a cluster of five genes encoding TNFR homologs [1] [6].
We found ______ mRNA in several peripheral tissues, and detected ______ protein on cultured vascular endothelial cells.
The levels of _____ mRNA in tissues were generally low; in peripheral blood T cells, however, antigen-receptor stimulation led to a substantial induction of _____ transcripts.

Cotransfection of ______ and _____ in embryonic kidney 293 cells activated the anti-apoptotic transcription factor _________, via a pathway that appeared to involve ________________________ (_____) [7] and _________________________ (___) [8].
Cotransfection of ______ and _____ in Jurkat T leukemia cells inhibited antigen-receptor-induced cell death.
Thus, ______ and _____ may modulate T lymphocyte survival in peripheral tissues.
A newly identified member of tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily (___) suppresses _____-mediated apoptosis.
___ (________________ (____)) is a new member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor (TNFR) family.
___ mRNA is expressed in lung tissues and colon adenocarcinoma, SW480.
In addition, the expression of ___ mRNA was shown in the endothelial cell line and induced by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate/ionomycin in Jurkat T leukemia cells.
The open reading frame of ___ encodes 300 amino acids with a 29-residue signal sequence but no transmembrane region.
Using histidine-tagged recombinant ___, we screened soluble forms of TNF-ligand proteins with immunoprecipitation.
Here, we demonstrate that ___ specifically binds two cellular ligands, _____ (____________________________________) and __________ (____/_____).
These bindings were confirmed with HEK 293 EBNA cells transfected with _____ cDNA by flow cytometry.
___ inhibited _____-induced cytotoxicity in HT29 cells.
It has been shown that _____ triggers apoptosis of various tumor cells including HT29 cells that express both _________________________ (_______) and ____/___ receptors.
Our data suggest that ___ inhibits the interactions of _____ with ____/___ and _______, thereby suppressing _____- mediated HT29 cell death.
Thus, ___ may play a regulatory role for suppressing in ____- and _____-mediated cell death.
Presenilins interact with _____, a small GTPase involved in the regulation of vesicular transport.
____________ (___) mutations account for the majority of early-onset dominant cases of familial Alzheimer's disease.
Presenilins (PSs) are located in many intra-cellular compartments such as the endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, nuclear region and vesicular structures.
These proteins include from seven to nine putative transmembrane domains, with the N- and C-terminal ends and a large hydrophilic loop orientated towards the cytoplasm.
We report an interaction between the human ___ or ___ hydrophilic loop and _____, a small GTPase belonging to the Ras-related superfamily.
Interaction domains were mapped to codons 374-400 for ___ and to codons 106-179 for _____, a region including the fourth GTP-binding domain.
Considering the implication of Rab proteins in vesicular transport pathways, the PS-_____ inter-action suggests that PSs might be involved in amyloid precursor protein vesicular routing.
Molecular cloning of a novel human CC chemokine (_________) that is a functional ligand of _______________________.

Previously, we mapped the novel CC chemokine ______________________________________ (______)/_________ to chromosome 7q11.23 (Nomiyama, H., Osborne, L. R., Imai, T., Kusuda, J., Miura, R., Tsui, L.-C., and Yoshie, O. (1998) Genomics 49, 339-340).
Since chemokine genes tend to be clustered, unknown chemokines may be present in the vicinity of those mapped to new chromosomal loci.
Prompted by this hypothesis, we analyzed the genomic region containing the gene for ______/_________ (______) and have identified a novel CC chemokine termed _________.
The genes for ______/_________ (______) and _________ (______) are localized within a region of approximately 40 kilobases.
By Northern blot analysis, _________ mRNA was constitutively expressed in the heart and ovary.
We have generated recombinant _________ in a baculovirus expression system.
_________ induced transient calcium mobilization specifically in _______________________ (____)-expressing L1.2 cells with an EC(50) of 3 nM.
_________ competed the binding of (125)_________ to ____-expressing L1.2 cells with an IC(50) of 13 nM.
_________ was chemotactic for normal peripheral blood eosinophils and basophils at high concentrations.
Collectively, _________ is yet another functional ligand for ____.
The potency of _________ as a ____ ligand seems, however, to be approximately 10-fold less than that of _______.
Identification of _________ will further promote our understanding of the control of eosinophil trafficking and other ____-mediated biological phenomena.
The strategy used in this study may also be applicable to identification of other unknown chemokine genes.
Design, characterization, and structure of a biologically active single-chain mutant of human _________.
A mutant form of human ________________ (_____________) that binds one ______________________________ (_________________) has been designed and characterized.
_____________ was derived by linking the two peptide chains of the _________ dimer by a seven-residue linker and changing His111 in the first chain to an aspartic acid residue.
Isothermal titration calorimetry shows that _____________ forms a 1:1 complex with its high-affinity receptor (_________________) with an affinity of 27(+/- 9) nM.
The crystal structure of _____________ has been determined at 2.9 A resolution from crystals grown in 1.4 M citrate solutions at pH 7.6.

Comparison of the wild-type receptor-binding domain and the Asp111-containing domain of _____________ show that they are structurally equivalent but have very different electrostatic surface potentials.
As a result, surface charge rather than structural changes is likely responsible for the inability of the His111-->Asp domain of to bind _________________.
The AB loops of _____________ adopt conformations similar to the ordered loops of _________ observed in the crystal structure of the _________/_________________ complex.
Thus, _________________ binding does not result in a large conformational change in the AB loop as previously suggested.
The structure also reveals the final six C-terminal amino acid residues of _____________ (residues 253-258) that have not been observed in any other reported _________ structures.
Despite binding to only one _________________, _____________ is biologically active in cell proliferation, MHC class I induction, and anti-viral assays.
This suggests that one domain of _________ is sufficient to recruit _________________ and ________________ into a complex competent for eliciting biological activity.
The current data are consistent with the main role of the _________ dimer being to decrease the dissociation constant of _________ for its cellular receptors.
Human ______________________________________/_____ is a functional ligand for ____, ____ and ____, and constitutively expressed by hepatocytes.
_________________________ (___)/_____ is a human CC chemokine selectively expressed in the liver.
Here, we investigated its receptor usage by calcium mobilization and chemotactic assays using mouse L1.2 pre-B cell lines stably expressing a panel of 12 human chemokine receptors.
At relatively high concentrations, ___ induced calcium mobilization and chemotaxis via ____ and ____.
___ also induced calcium mobilization, but marginal chemotaxis via ____.
Consistently, ___ was found to bind to ____, ____ and ____ with relatively low affinities.
The binding of ___ to ____ was much less significant.
In spite of its binding to ____, ___ was unable to inhibit infection of an R5-type HIV-1 to activated human peripheral blood mononuclear cells even at high concentrations.
In human liver sections, hepatocytes were strongly stained by anti-LEC antibody.
HepG2, a human hepatocarcinoma cell line, was found to constitutively express ___.
___ was also present in the plasma samples from healthy adult donors at relatively high concentrations (0.3--4 nM).
Taken together, ___ is a new low-affinity functional ligand for ____, ____ and ____, and is constitutively expressed by liver parenchymal cells.
The presence of ___ in normal plasma at relatively high concentrations may modulate inflammatory responses.
Crystal structure of human _________________________________.
The crystal structure of the homodimeric ______________________________________________________________ (_______) has been determined by X-ray analysis to 3.0 A resolution.
The polypeptide chain is folded into two highly twisted antiparallel pairs of beta-strands and contains an unusual knotted arrangement of three intramolecular disulfide bonds.
Dimerization leads to the clustering of three surface loops at each end of the elongated dimer, which most probably form the receptor recognition sites.
Human ________, a new cyclin that interacts with two members of the ____ gene family.
A new human cyclin, named ________, was isolated by complementation of a triple cln deletion in S. cerevisiae.
________ showed genetic interactions with the _____ gene, suggesting that it functioned at START by interacting with the _____ protein.
Two human genes were identified that could interact with ________ to perform START in yeast containing a _____ mutation.
One was _______, and the second was the human homolog of Xenopus ____.
________ produced in E. coli bound and activated the ____ protein in extracts from human G1 cells, and antibodies against ________ immunoprecipitated a histone H1 kinase from HeLa cells.
The interactions between ________ and ____, or ____, may be important at the G1 to S transition in human cells.
A cellular protein that competes with ______________ for binding to the ______________ gene product.
Tumour-suppressor genes, such as the human __________________________________ (__), are widely recognized as being vital in the control of cell growth and tumour formation.
This role is indicated, in part, by the suppression of tumorigenicity of human tumour cells after retrovirus-mediated __ replacement.

How __ acts to bring about this suppression is not clear but one clue is that the __ protein forms complexes with the transforming oncoproteins of several DNA tumour viruses, and that two regions of __ essential for such binding frequently contain mutations in tumour cells.
These observations suggest that endogenous cellular proteins might exist that bind to the same regions of __ and thereby mediate its function.
We report here the identification of one such human cellular _____________________ of relative molecular mass 46,000 (46K) (______).

Two lines of evidence support the notion that ______ and _________________________ have homologous __-binding properties: first, several mutated __ proteins that failed to bind to T also did not associate with ______; and second, both T antigen and T peptide (amino acids 101-118) were able to compete with ______ for binding to __.
The apparent targeting of the ______-__ interaction by oncoproteins of DNA tumour viruses strongly suggests that formation of this complex is functionally important.
Evidence for a differential interaction of ___ and the ____________________________ (_____) with the _____________________________________________ in the yeast two-hybrid system.

Using the yeast two-hybrid system, a genetic assay for studying protein-protein interactions, we have examined and compared the interaction of the _____________________________________ (______) and the ________________ (__) with their two known substrates ______ and the ____________________________ (_____).
We also mapped the specific domains of the ______ and ______ participating in these interactions.

Our findings can be summarized as follows: (i) the tyrosine kinase activity of the ______ is essential for the interaction with ______ and _____, (ii) ______ and _____ bind to the ______ in the NPEY-juxtamembrane motif, (iii) contrary to ______, _____ binds also to the major autophosphorylation sites (Tyr-1131, -1135, and -1136) of the ______, and (iv) the amino-terminal domain of ______ is required for its association with the __ and the ______.

We propose that (i) the ______ and the __ share at least in part the same molecular mechanism underlying their interplay with their two substrates, ______ and _____, and (ii) _____ interacts with the ______ in a fashion that is different from that used by ______.
Finally, our data highlight the crucial role of the juxtamembrane domain in signaling by both the __ and the ______.
Correlation of two-hybrid affinity data with in vitro measurements.
Since their introduction, the interaction trap and other two-hybrid systems have been used to study protein-protein interactions.

Despite their general use, little is known about the extent to which the degree of protein interaction determined by two-hybrid approaches parallels the degree of interaction determined by biochemical techniques.
In this study, we used a set of lexAop-LEU2 and lexAop-lacZ reporters to calibrate the interaction trap.
For the calibration, we used two sets of proteins, the ___-___-____ helix-loop-helix proteins, and wild-type and dimerization-defective versions of the lambda cI repressor.

Our results indicate that the strength of interaction as predicted by the two-hybrid approach generally correlates with that determined in vitro, permitting discrimination of high-, intermediate-, and low-affinity interactions, but there was no single reporter for which the amount of gene expression linearly reflected affinity measured in vitro.
However, some reporters showed thresholds and only responded to stronger interactions.
Finally, some interactions were subject to directionality, and their apparent strength depended on the reporter used.
Taken together, our results provide a cautionary framework for interpreting affinities from two-hybrid experiments.
Interaction of the protein ____________ with __________, as revealed by the yeast two-hybrid system.
The heterotrimeric G protein, __________, transduces signals from seven membrane spanning receptors to effectors such as adenylyl cyclase and ion channels.
The purpose of this study was to identify these or other cellular proteins that interact with __________ by use of the yeast two-hybrid system.
A human B cell cDNA library was screened by this system using full length __________.
Four positive colonies were obtained.

Two of the four were identified as ____________, a calcium binding protein and a putative antigen to which anti-nuclear antibodies are generated in mice with a disorder that resembles systemic lupus erythematosus.
____________ has a leucine zipper, EF hands, and a signal peptide sequence and is thought to localize to the nucleus as well as being secreted.
The specificity of intehraction between __________ and ____________ was confirmed by an in vitro binding assay using recombinant proteins.
Transfection of __________ and ____________ in COS cells increased __________ expression relative to cells transfected with __________ and mock vector.
Our results indicate that the yeast two-hybrid system provides a means to identify novel proteins that interact with G alpha proteins.
____________ appears to represent one of those proteins.
____ interaction with _________________ ties mitogenic signal transduction to cell cycle activation.
The ___ and ____ proto-oncogenes transduce extracellular signals that promote cell growth.
Cdc25 phosphatases activate the cell division cycle by dephosphorylation of critical threonine and tyrosine residues within the cyclin-dependent kinases.
We show here that _________________ associates with ____ in somatic mammalian cells and in meiotic frog oocytes.
Furthermore, _________________ can be activated in vitro in a ____-dependent manner.
We suggest that activation of the cell cycle by the ___/____ pathways might be mediated in part by _____.
A direct interaction between ____________________ subunits and the ____________________.
_____ is a serine/threonine protein kinase positioned downstream of ___ in the ________________________________ cascade.

Using a yeast two-hybrid strategy to identify other proteins that interact with and potentially regulate _____, we isolated a clone encoding the carboxyl-terminal half of the ________________ of heterotrimeric G-proteins.
In vitro, purified ____________ subunits specifically bound to a GST fusion protein encoding amino acids 1-330 of _____ (_______).
Binding assays with truncation mutants of GST-___ indicate that the region located between amino acids 136 and 239 is a primary determinant for interaction with ____________.

In competition experiments, the carboxyl terminus of _______________________________ (________) blocked the binding of ____________ to _______; however, the _____-binding proteins, ___ and 14-3-3, had no effect.

Scatchard analysis of in vitro binding between _______ and ____________ revealed an affinity of interaction (Kd = 163 +/- 36 nM), similar to that seen between ____________ and ________ (Kd = 87 +/- 24 nM).

The formation of native heterotrimeric __________________ complexes, as measured by pertussis toxin ADP-ribosylation of G alpha, could be disrupted by increasing amounts of _______, with an EC50 of approximately 200 nM, in close agreement with the estimated binding affinity.
In vivo complexes of _____ and ____________ were isolated from human embryonic kidney 293-T cells transfected with epitope-tagged ________.

The identification and characterization of this novel interaction raises several possibilities for signaling cross-talk between growth factor receptors and those receptors coupled to heterotrimeric G-proteins.

Mutagenesis of the regulatory subunit (________) of _____________________________________ reveals hydrophobic amino acids that are essential for ________ dimerization and/or anchoring ________ to the cytoskeleton.

In neurons _____________________________________ (__________) is sequestered in the dendritic cytoskeleton because the regulatory subunit (________) of the enzyme is tightly bound by A Kinase Anchor Proteins (AKAPs).
The prototypic neuronal anchor protein ______ has a COOH-terminal 22-residue ________ binding (tethering) site.
A key feature of the tethering site is that several amino acids with large aliphatic side chains mediate the high-affinity binding of ________.
Mutagenesis, recombinant protein expression, and physicochemical characterization were used to investigate the structural basis for the homodimerization and ______ binding activities of ________.
Several crucial residues are located in an NH2-terminal region that encompasses amino acids 13-36.
Substitution of Ala for Leu13 or Phe36 generates monomeric ________ subunits that cannot bind ______.

The results are not due to general misfolding since mutant ________ monomers bind cAMP and inhibit the catalytic subunit of __________ with the same affinity and efficacy as wild-type ________ dimers.
Moreover, substitution of Ala for Leu12, Val20, Leu21, Phe31, Leu33, or Leu39 and replacement of Leu13 with Ile or Val did not impair the dimerization reaction.
Evidently, large hydrophobic side chains of Leu13 and Phe36 play pivotal roles in stabilizing ________-________ interactions.
A secondary consequence of destabilizing ________ dimers is the loss of intracellular targeting/anchoring capacity because monomers fail to bind ______.
Other NH2-terminal residues directly modulate the affinity of ________ dimers for the ______ tethering site.
Replacement of Val20-Leu21 with Ala-Ala produced a dimeric ________ protein that binds ______ approximately 4% as avidly as wild-type ________.
It is possible that the aliphatic side chains of Val20 and Leu21 interact with the essential Leu and Ile residues in the ______ tethering region.
____: a protein kinase stimulated by UV light and ______ that binds and phosphorylates the _____ activation domain.
The ultraviolet (UV) response of mammalian cells is characterized by a rapid and selective increase in gene expression mediated by ____ and __________.
The effect on ____ transcriptional activity results, in part, from enhanced phosphorylation of the _____ NH2-terminal activation domain.
Here, we describe the molecular cloning and characterization of ____, a distant relative of the __________ group that is activated by dual phosphorylation at Thr and Tyr during the UV response.
Significantly, ______ partially activates ____ and potentiates the activation caused by UV.
____ binds to the _____ transactivation domain and phosphorylates it on Ser-63 and Ser-73.
Thus, ____ is a component of a novel signal transduction pathway that is activated by oncoproteins and UV irradiation.
These properties indicate that ____ activation may play an important role in tumor promotion.
A protein ligand for the ____________________________________ has been isolated by using the extracellular domain (___-X) of the receptor as an affinity reagent.
Initially, concentrated cell culture supernatants were screened for receptor binding activity using immobilized ___-X in a surface plasmon resonance detection system.

Subsequently, supernatants from selected cell lines were fractionated directly by receptor affinity chromatography, resulting in the single-step purification of ___, a protein previously identified as the product of an early response gene induced by ____________________________.
We report here that recombinant ___ induces autophosphorylation of ___ in intact cells, consistent with ___ being an authentic ligand for ___.

___ is a member of a large orphan receptor protein-tyrosine kinase family headed by EPH, and we suggest that ligands for other members of this family will be related to ___, and can be isolated in the same way.
____, a human G1 and S phase protein phosphatase that associates with ____.
We used the interaction trap, a yeast genetic selection for interacting proteins, to isolate human ____________________________________ (____).
In yeast, ____ interacts with cyclin-dependent kinases, including human ____, ____, and ____, but not with ____.
In HeLa cells, ____ is expressed at the G1 to S transition, and the protein forms stable complexes with ____.
____ bears weak sequence similarity to known tyrosine and dual specificity phosphatases.
In vitro, ____ removes phosphate from tyrosine residues in model substrates, but a mutant protein that bears a lesion in the putative active site cysteine does not.
Overexpression of wild-type ____ delays progression through the cell cycle in yeast and HeLa cells; delay is dependent on ____ phosphatase activity.
These experiments identify ____ as a novel type of protein phosphatase that forms complexes with cyclin-dependent kinases.
The SH2/SH3 domain-containing protein ____ interacts with tyrosine-phosphorylated ____ and ___: implications for insulin control of ___ signalling.
____, a small protein comprising one SH2 domain and two SH3 domains, represents the human homologue of the Caenorhabditis elegans protein, _____.
Both ____ and _____ have been implicated in a highly conserved mechanism that regulates ______ signalling by receptor tyrosine kinases.
In this report we show that in response to _______, ____ forms a stable complex with two tyrosine-phosphorylated proteins.
One protein is the major insulin receptor substrate _____ and the second is the SH2 domain-containing oncogenic protein, ___.

The interactions between ____ and these two proteins require ligand activation of the ________________ and are mediated by the binding of the SH2 domain of ____ to phosphotyrosines on both _____ and ___.
Although ____ associates with _____ and ___, it is not tyrosine-phosphorylated after _______ stimulation, implying that ____ is not a substrate for the insulin receptor.
Furthermore, we have identified a short sequence motif (YV/IN) present in _____, ____ and ___, which specifically binds the SH2 domain of ____ with high affinity.

Interestingly, both ____ and ____________________________________ can simultaneously bind distinct tyrosine phosphorylated regions on the same _____ molecule, suggesting a mechanism whereby _____ could provide the core for a large signalling complex.
We propose a model whereby insulin stimulation leads to formation of multiple protein--protein interactions between ____ and the two targets _____ and ___.
These interactions may play a crucial role in activation of ______ and the control of downstream effector molecules.
A histone octamer-like structure within _____.

The general transcription factor _____ nucleates initiation complex formation through direct core promoter binding, commits promoters within chromatin to transcription, and mediates the action of transcriptional activators, a phenomenon that may correlate with enhanced _____ recruitment or conformational changes in _____-promoter complexes.

Molecular studies of the multiprotein _____ complex have identified a primary ____________________ (___), TBP-associated factors (TAFs) that interact with and mediate the function of activators and intersubunit interactions but have yielded relatively little insight into the structural organization of the complex or the actual mechanism of transcriptional activation.
Here we present biochemical evidence for the structural relevance of histone homologies in the human _____ subunits ______, ______ and _________.
Together with analyses of native _____ complexes and accompanying crystallographic studies, the results suggest that there is a histone octamer-like TAF complex within _____.
____: a kinase associated with the ______________________.
The pleiotropic biological activities of _____________ (____) are mediated by its type I receptor (______).
When the ligand binds, ______ initiates a signaling cascade that results in the activation of the transcription regulator ______________________ (__________).
A protein kinase designated ____ (_______________________________) was purified, and its complementary DNA was molecularly cloned.
When human embryonic kidney cells (cell line 293) over-expressing ______ or HeLa cells were exposed to ____, ____ rapidly associated with the ______ complex and was phosphorylated.
The primary amino acid sequence of ____ shares similarity with that of pelle,a protein kinase that is essential for the activation of a __________ homolog in Drosophila.
Elimination of false negative results in the two-hybrid system in the phagocyte _____________.
The yeast two-hybrid system is finding increased use in the study of interactions between proteins.
In this method, two polypeptides are expressed in yeast as fusion proteins to a transcriptional activator DNA-binding domain (bd) and activating domain (ad), respectively.
Interaction between the two polypeptides reconstitutes function of a transactivator which controls expression of reporters.

The phagocyte _____________ is a complex of membrane _______________ (comprised of subunits ________ and _________) and three cytosol proteins (________, ________, and ______) that translocate to membrane and bind to _______________.
This is the first report to demonstrate that two of cytosolic components of _______________, ________ binding to ________ each other.
We encountered several methodological problems in the two-hybrid system which are the focus of this report.
Formation of ___-CDK complexes during the human mitotic cell cycle.
In eukaryotic cells, the coordinated activation of different cyclin-dependent kinases regulates entry into S-phase.
In vitro and in nonproliferating cells, ___ associates with and inhibits cyclin/cycin-dependent kinase (CDK) holoenzymes containing either ____, ____, or ____.

Although many different types of proliferating cells contain ___ protein, neither the interactions of ___ with cyclin/CDK complexes nor the consequences of this interaction during the mitotic cycle have been fully explored.
We report that, in MANCA cells, the amount of ___ is constant during the cell cycle.
In addition, ___ associates with three different CDKs: ____, ____, and ____.
Furthermore, the amount of ___ is significantly lower than the amount of _________ in these cells.

The amount of ____ and ____ associated with ___ does not change in a cell cycle-dependent fashion; in contrast, the amount of ____ associated with ___ is lowest in early G1 cells and increases to a maximum in mid-G1 phase, reaching a steady-state level in late G1-phase cells.
After mid-G1 phase, the amount of each ___/CDK complex remains constant through the remainder of the cell cycle.
___-immunoprecipitates contain an Rb-kinase activity.

The substrate specificity, the expression pattern of this kinase, and the ability to deplete 50% of this kinase activity with a ____-specific antibody suggest that the ____ protein mediates, in part, the ___-associated __-kinase activity.
In contrast, ___ complexes containing ____ are incapable of phosphorylating __________.
These data are consistent with a model wherein ________/CDK complexes sequester the ____-dependent kinase inhibitory activity of ___.
Structure of the ___ tumor suppressor bound to the ankyrin and SH3 domains of _____.
Mutations in the ___ tumor suppressor are among the most frequently observed genetic alterations in human cancer and map to the 200-amino acid core domain of the protein.
The core domain contains the sequence-specific DNA binding activity and the in vitro _____ protein binding activity of ___.

The crystal structure of the ___ core domain bound to the _____ protein, which contains an SH3 (Src homology 3) domain and four ankyrin repeats, revealed that (i) the SH3 domain binds the L3 loop of ___ in a manner distinct from that of previously characterized SH3-polyproline peptide complexes, and (ii) an ankyrin repeat, which forms an L-shaped structure consisting of a beta hairpin and two alpha helices, binds the L2 loop of ___.

The structure of the complex shows that the _____ binding site on the ___ core domain consists of evolutionarily conserved regions that are frequently mutated in cancer and that it overlaps the site of DNA binding.
The six most frequently observed ___ mutations disrupt _____ binding in vitro.
The structure provides evidence that the _____-___ complex forms in vivo and may have a critical role in the ___ pathway of tumor suppression.
cDNA cloning and characterization of the human ___________________________________.
We have cloned cDNAs corresponding to the human ___________________________________ (___________).
The protein has 76% homology to murine ___________, with 95% amino acid identity in the cytoplasmic domain.

Only weak _____ binding activity was found in cells transfected with only ___________; however, the combination of both ___________ and __________ resulted in substantial binding activity, with a Kd of approximately 400 pM, indicating that both chains are essential components of the ______________.

Whereas ___________ serves as an alternative accessory protein to the common _____________________________ (______) for ____ signaling, it could not replace the function of ______ in allowing enhanced ____ binding activity.
Nevertheless, the overall size and length of the cytoplasmic domain of ___________ and ______ are similar, and like ______, ___________ is located on chromosome X.
SREBP transcriptional activity is mediated through an interaction with the ____________________.
The sterol regulatory element binding proteins (_______ and -2) activate transcription of genes whose products are involved in the cellular uptake and synthesis of cholesterol.
Although considerable effort has been exerted to define the events regulating the levels of active SREBP, little is known about the transcriptional cofactors mediating SREBP function.
In an unbiased search for potential coactivators of SREBP, we isolated a protein of 265 kD from HeLa cells that directly bound _______ and _______.
Peptide sequencing and Western blot analysis established that the 265-kD protein was ___ (____________________),a recently identified transcriptional coactivator.
The putative activation domain of SREBP was shown to bind specifically to amino-terminal domains of recombinant ___ and ____ (a ___-related protein).
Moreover, transfection studies demonstrated that ___ enhances the ability of SREBP to activate transcription of reporter genes in HeLa cells.
Together, these data suggest that ___ mediates SREBP transcriptional activity, thus revealing a new step in the biochemical pathway regulating cholesterol metabolism.
Associations of _____ with _____, ____, ___, and _____ proteins in a yeast two-hybrid system.
The yeast _____-dependent pathway is involved in DNA recombination and double-strand break repair.
Yeast ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme ____ participates in S- and M-phase cyclin degradation and mitotic control.

Using the human _____ protein as the "bait" in a yeast two-hybrid system, we have identified a human homolog of yeast ____, designated _____, that interacts with _____, _____, ___, and a ubiquitin-like protein ____.
These interactions are _____-specific, since another DNA repair-related ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme, ____ (____), does not interact with these proteins.
The interaction of _____ with _____ is mediated by _____'s self-association region.
These results suggest that the _____-dependent processes, cell cycle control, ___-mediated pathway(s), and ubiquitination interact through human _____.
Efficient interaction of HIV-1 with purified dendritic cells via multiple chemokine coreceptors.
HIV-1 actively replicates in dendritic cell (DC)-T cell cocultures, but it has been difficult to demonstrate substantial infection of purified mature DCs.
We now find that HIV-1 begins reverse transcription much more efficiently in DCs than T cells, even though T cells have higher levels of ___ and _____ binding.
DCs isolated from skin or from blood precursors behave similarly.

Several M-tropic strains and the T-tropic strain IIIB enter DCs efficiently, as assessed by the progressive formation of the early products of reverse transcription after a 90-min virus pulse at 37 degrees C.
However, few late gag-containing sequences are detected, so that active viral replication does not occur.
The formation of these early transcripts seems to follow entry of HIV-1, rather than binding of virions that contain viral DNA.
Early transcripts are scarce if DCs are exposed to virus on ice for 4 h, or for 90 min at 37 degrees C, conditions which allow virus binding.
Also the early transcripts once formed are insensitive to _______.
The entry of a M-tropic isolates is blocked by the chemokine ______, and the entry of IIIB by SDF-1.
______ interacts with ____ and _____ with _____ receptors.
Entry of M-tropic but not T-tropic virus is ablated in DCs from individuals who lack a functional ____ receptor.
DCs express more ____ and _____ mRNA than T cells.
Therefore, while HIV-1 does not replicate efficiently in mature DCs, viral entry can be active and can be blocked by chemokines that act on known receptors for M- and T-tropic virus.
Identification of interaction partners for the basic-helix-loop-helix protein ___.
Helix-loop-helix proteins constitute a family of transcription factors with the potential to form homo- and hetero-dimers mediated by the helix-loop-helix domain.
Oncogenic mutations in such genes can disrupt the equilibrium of protein-protein interactions in the affected cell.
In order to assess the biological consequences of such mutations, the full complement of interacting proteins must be known.

To identify proteins interacting with the basic-helix-loop-helix domain of the ubiquitously expressed ___ protein, a 'sandwich'-screening procedure was developed which distinguishes between homo- and hetero-oligomers, and specifically excludes the detection of complexes which cannot bind DNA.

Nine distinct cDNAs were identified which encode proteins with apparent basic-helix-loop-helix domains, including a novel clone termed ____ which is distantly related in the basic-helix-loop-helix domain to the Drosophila enhancer-of-split m7 protein.
Using epitope-tagging, interaction of ___ basic-helix-loop-helix protein with the ____ protein encoded by this novel cDNA was confirmed by immunoprecipitation experiments in COS7 cells.
Interaction was also observed in the yeast two-hybrid system.
Three cDNAs encoding proteins without basic-helix-loop-helix domains were also found to interact in the sandwich-expression screen.
Interactions with human ____ and mouse _____________________ were confirmed using glutathione transferase-tagged cDNAs.
A cDNA encoding part of the _________ protein sequence interacted with the ___ basic-helix-loop-helix only when fused to a beta-galactosidase tag.
___________________________ is a transcriptional modulator that communicates with ________________________ and the ___________________________.
__________________________n (___) transactivates viral and cellular genes through a wide variety of cis-elements.
However, the mechanism is still obscure.

Our finding that ___ directly interacts with ___________________________ (____), a common subunit of RNA polymerases, implies that ___ directly modulates the function of RNA polymerase (Cheong, J. H., Yi, M., Lin, Y., and Murakami, S. (1995) EMBO J. 14, 142-150).
In this context, we examined the possibility that ___ and ____ interact with other general transcription factors.
___ and ____ specifically bound to ________________________ (_____) in vitro, both of which were detected by either far-Western blotting or the glutathione S-transferase-resin pull-down assay.
Delineation of the binding regions of these three proteins revealed that ___, ____, and _____ each has two binding regions for the other two proteins.
Co-immunoprecipitation using HepG2 cell lysates that express ___ demonstrated trimeric interaction in vivo.

Some ___ substitution mutants, which had severely impaired transacting activity, exhibited reduced binding affinity with either _____ or ____ in a mutually exclusive manner, suggesting that ___ transactivation requires the interactions of both ____ and _____.

These results indicated that ___ is a novel virus modulator that facilitates transcriptional initiation by stabilizing the association between RNA polymerase and _____ through communication with ____ and _____.
A new cytokine-receptor binding mode revealed by the crystal structure of the _____________ with an antagonist.

Inflammation, regardless of whether it is provoked by infection or by tissue damage, starts with the activation of macrophages which initiate a cascade of inflammatory responses by producing the cytokines _____________ (____) and ____________________________ (ref. 1).
Three naturally occurring ligands for the _____________ (____) exist: the agonists _________ and ________ and the ________________________ _____ (ref. 2).
____ is the only cytokine for which a naturally occurring antagonist is known.
Here we describe the crystal structure at 2.7 A resolution of the soluble extracellular part of ___________ complexed with _____.
The receptor consists of three immunoglobulin-like domains.
Domains 1 and 2 are tightly linked, but domain three is completely separate and connected by a flexible linker.
Residues of all three domains contact the antagonist and include the five critical _____ residues which were identified by site-directed mutagenesis.
A region that is important for biological function in ________, the 'receptor trigger site' is not in direct contact with the receptor in the _____ complex.
Modelling studies suggest that this ________ trigger site might induce a movement of domain 3.
Cross-family interaction between the bHLHZip ___ and bZip ____ proteins results in down-regulation of ___ activity.

Heterodimerization among the basic-leucine zipper (bZIP) proteins or among the basic-helix-loop-helix-leucine zipper (bHLHZip) proteins confers a multitude of combinational activities to these transcription factors.
To further examine the function of the bHLHZip protein, ___, we screened for cellular proteins which could directly interact with ___ using the yeast two-hybrid system.
A bZip protein, ____, was found to efficiently interact with ___.
___ specifically interacts with ____ but not with other closely related family members, _____, ____, ____, or with _____.
Both the bHLHZip and the N-terminal regions of ____ are required for efficient interaction with ___.
In vivo association between ___ and ____ has been demonstrated by co-immunoprecipitation.
Expression of exogenous ___ led to a decrease in ___-dependent transcription in F9 cells.
Co-expression of exogenous ____ restored the ___ activity in a dose-dependent manner.
These data show that ___ and ____ physically and functionally interact demonstrating that cross-talk occurs between factors of distantly related transcription families.
Interaction between ___ protein and _____ in response to DNA damage.

The gene mutated in the autosomal recessive disorder ataxia telangiectasia (AT), designated ___ (for '__________'), is a member of a family of phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase-like enzymes that are involved in cell-cycle control, meiotic recombination, telomere length monitoring and DNA-damage response.
Previous results have demonstrated that AT cells are hypersensitive to ionizing radiation and are defective at the G1/S checkpoint after radiation damage.

Because cells lacking the protein tyrosine kinase _____ are also defective in radiation-induced G1 arrest, we investigated the possibility that ___ might interact with _____ in response to radiation damage.
Here we show that ___ binds _____ constitutively in control cells but not in AT cells.
Our results demonstrate that the SH3 domain of _____ interacts with a DPAPNPPHFP motif (residues 1,373-1,382) of ___.
The results also reveal that radiation-induction of _____ tyrosine kinase activity is diminished in AT cells.
These findings indicate that ___ is involved in the activation of _____ by DNA damage and this interaction may in part mediate radiation-induced G1 arrest.
A region of the beta subunit of the _________________________ different from box 1 interacts with ____ and is sufficient to activate the ___-Stat pathway and induce an antiviral state.
Coexpression of the alpha and betaL subunits of the human ____________________________________ is required for the induction of an antiviral state by human ________.
To explore the role of the different domains of the betaL subunit in ________ signaling, we coexpressed wild-type alpha subunit and truncated forms of the betaL chain in L-929 cells.

Our results demonstrated that the first 82 amino acids (AAs) (AAs 265-346) of the cytoplasmic domain of the betaL chain are sufficient to activate the ___-Stat pathway and trigger an antiviral state after _________ binding to the receptor.
This region of the betaL chain, required for ____ binding and activation, contains the Box 1 motif that is important for the interaction of some cytokine receptors with ___ kinases.

However, using glutathione S-transferase fusion proteins containing amino- and carboxyl-terminal deletions of the betaL cytoplasmic domain, we demonstrate that the main ____-binding region (corresponding to AAs 300-346 on the beta subunit) is distinct from the Box 1 domain (AAs 287-295).
Interaction between cell cycle regulator, _____, and _________ mediates repression of HIV-1 gene transcription.
The _________/___ family of transcription factors is one of the main targets of cytokines and other agents that induce HIV-1 gene expression.
Some of these extracellular stimuli arrest cells in the G1 phase of the mitotic division cycle and modulate the activity of the tumor suppressor protein __ and its partner _____.

Earlier studies indicated that _____, a transcription factor that stimulates expression of S-phase-specific genes, is able to repress transcription directed by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV-1) type-1 promoter in a variety of cells, including those of glial and lymphocytic origin.

Here, we demonstrate that _____ may regulate the activity of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat through its ability to bind sequences in the _________ enhancer region and to interact with the _________ subunit, ___.
Gel retardation and methylation interference assays show that _____ is able to bind specifically to a site embedded within the two _________ elements.
Gel retardation/immunoblot analysis using purified _____ and ___ homodimers reveals the presence of complexes containing both proteins.
Affinity chromatography and co-immunoprecipitation assays provide evidence for direct interaction of _____ and ___ in the absence of their DNA target sequences.
In vitro transcription assay demonstrates that _____ represses _________ mediated transcription in a cell-free system.
Functional studies in Jurkat T lymphocytic cells point to the importance of both the ___ and _________ binding sites in _____ mediated repression of HIV-1 promoter, in vivo.
The results of this study suggest that _________ activity may be regulated by its interaction with the cell cycle regulatory protein, _____.
